| Name                                                              | mirror                           |
| Appearance                                                        | looking glass                    |
| Base price                                                        | 10 [zm](/wiki/Zorkmid "Zorkmid") |
| Weight                                                            | [13](/wiki/Weight "Weight")      |
| Material                                                          | [glass](/wiki/Glass "Glass")     |
| Monster use                                                       | *Will not be used by monsters.*  |

A **mirror**, known as a **looking glass** when not [identified](/wiki/Identified "Identified"), is a type of [tool](/wiki/Tool "Tool") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)
- [2 Effects](#Effects)
- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [4 Messages](#Messages)
  - [4.1 Vanity](#Vanity)
- [5 Artifacts](#Artifacts)
- [6 References](#References)
- [7 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

## Generation

[Nymphs](/wiki/Nymph "Nymph") are often seen with mirrors, and have a 50% chance of [being generated with one](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory").

## Effects

[Applying](/wiki/Apply "Apply") a mirror to a [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") can [scare](/wiki/Scare "Scare") it; this only works if they can see it, i.e. they are not [eyeless](/wiki/Eyeless "Eyeless") or [blind](/wiki/Blind "Blind"), and you must not be [invisible](/wiki/Invisible "Invisible") (unless the monster can also [see invisible](/wiki/See_invisible "See invisible")). There is an 80% chance of the foe fleeing for 2d4 turns, unless one of the special cases below occurs.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) [Humanoid](/wiki/Humanoid "Humanoid") foes and [unicorns](/wiki/Unicorn "Unicorn") are not fooled by a mirror and won't be frightened. A [cursed](/wiki/Cursed "Cursed") mirror only works half the time; the rest of the time it will "fog up" instead.

Applying a mirror to a nymph or a [foocubus](/wiki/Foocubus "Foocubus") (a succubus in [3.4.3](/wiki/3.4.3 "3.4.3")[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)) will not scare them; instead, the monster will steal the mirror and teleport away.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

Breaking a mirror gives a −2 penalty to [Luck](/wiki/Luck "Luck"). Hitting a monster with a wielded mirror will cause it to break and deal one point of damage; this damage also applies to [shades](/wiki/Shade "Shade"),[\[4\]](#cite_note-4) though this is not particularly useful.

## Strategy

Common uses of a mirror include applying it to monsters with [gaze](/wiki/Gaze "Gaze") attacks, such as [floating eyes](/wiki/Floating_eye "Floating eye"), [umber hulks](/wiki/Umber_hulk "Umber hulk") and [Medusa](/wiki/Medusa "Medusa"), in order to reflect them. However, it will not reflect the gaze of [Archons](/wiki/Archon "Archon"), [pyrolisks](/wiki/Pyrolisk "Pyrolisk"), or [Baalzebub](/wiki/Baalzebub "Baalzebub").

As nymphs are often generated with mirrors, it is a bad idea to attack them with spells of [force bolt](/wiki/Spellbook_of_force_bolt "Spellbook of force bolt") or any [wand of striking](/wiki/Wand_of_striking "Wand of striking") and risk your Luck. Mirrors can be used against nymphs and foocubi to prevent the theft of more desirable (and possibly dangerous) items and/or unwanted removal of armor.

The Luck penalty for breaking a mirror can be used to intentionally lower your Luck to prevent getting [crowned](/wiki/Crowned "Crowned") while praying.

## Messages

- The \<monster> is frightened by its reflection.

  You applied the mirror at a monster and frightened it.

- The \<monster> ignores \<his/her/its> reflection.

  You applied the mirror at a monster that cannot be frightened by it, or you failed to frighten it.

- \<Monster> doesn't have a reflection.

  You applied the mirror to a [vampire](/wiki/Vampire "Vampire") or [ghost](/wiki/Ghost "Ghost")

- The \<monster> admires \<him/her>self in your mirror. \<He/She> takes it!

  You applied the mirror at a nymph or foocubus.

- The \<monster> is too tired to look at your mirror.

  The monster is [asleep](/wiki/Asleep "Asleep").

- You reflect the ceiling.

  You applied the mirror up.

- You reflect the floor.

  You applied the mirror down.

- You reflect the murky water.

  You applied the mirror underwater.

- You give the fish a chance to fix their makeup.

  As above while hallucinating.

- You reflect \<monster>'s \<stomach/interior>.

  You applied the mirror at a monster who is engulfing you.

- The \<monster> can't see anything right now.

  The monster is blinded.

### Vanity

Applying a mirror at yourself will often produce [YAFM](/wiki/YAFM "YAFM"), particularly if you are [polymorphed](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph"). If more than one of the conditions apply, the message corresponding to the one that is highest on the list will be displayed.

- You look as ugly as ever.

  Your [charisma](/wiki/Charisma "Charisma") is 14 or lower.

- You look as handsome/beautiful as ever.

  Your charisma is 15 or higher.

- You can't see your ugly face.

  You have charisma of 14 or lower and are invisible, but can't see invisible, or are blind.

- You can't see your handsome/beautiful face.

  As above, but your charisma is 15 or higher.

- Yikes! You've frozen yourself!

  You are a [floating eye](/wiki/Floating_eye "Floating eye") without [free action](/wiki/Free_action "Free action"), and become [paralyzed](/wiki/Paralyzed "Paralyzed").)

- You don't have a reflection.

  You are a [vampire](/wiki/Vampire "Vampire").

- Huh? That doesn't look like you!

  You are an [umber hulk](/wiki/Umber_hulk "Umber hulk"), and become [confused](/wiki/Confused "Confused").)

- You look \<color>.

  You are hallucinating. \<color> is replaced with either ultraviolet, infrared, bluish-orange, reddish-green, dark white, light black, sky blue-pink, salty, sweet, sour, bitter, striped, spiral, swirly, plaid, checkered, argyle, paisley, blotchy, guernsey-spotted, polka-dotted, square, round, triangular, cabernet, sangria, fuchsia, wisteria, lemon-lime, strawberry-banana, peppermint, romantic, or incandescent.

- You look peaked.

  You are [sick](/wiki/Sick "Sick").

- You look undernourished.

  You are [weak](/wiki/Weak "Weak") or worse from hunger.

## Artifacts

[The Magic Mirror of Merlin](/wiki/The_Magic_Mirror_of_Merlin "The Magic Mirror of Merlin") is the only artifact mirror in the game. It cannot be broken like a normal mirror, as all artifacts are immune to breakage. It can, however, be stolen by a nymph or foocubus if applied at them, so doing so is a [bad idea](/wiki/Bad_idea "Bad idea").

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [apply.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 724](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/apply.c#line724 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/apply.c")
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [apply.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 715](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/apply.c#line715 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/apply.c")
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [apply.c in NetHack 3.6.0, line 901](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.0_Release/apply.c#L901)
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [shade\_aware](/wiki/Source:Uhitm.c#shade_aware "Source:Uhitm.c") in [Uhitm.c](/wiki/Source:Uhitm.c "Source:Uhitm.c")

## Encyclopedia entry

But as Snow White grew, she became more and more beautiful,  
and by the time she was seven years old she was as beautiful  
as the day and more beautiful than the queen herself. One  
day when the queen said to her mirror:  
   
       "Mirror, Mirror, here I stand.  
       Who is the fairest in the land?" -  
   
the mirror replied:  
   
       "You, O Queen, are the fairest here,  
       But Snow White is a thousand times more fair."

\[ Snow White, by Jakob and Wilhelm Grimm ]
